item.title: Sagas Quantatively: Fantasy Fiction
item.description: Last time, we discussed the first saga cataloged by Mark Richards and Neal Ford in their book, “Software Architecture: The Hard Parts”. We saw how the epic saga is exponentially sensitive to the availabilities of the orchestrator and the orchestrated services. We also noted how latency worsens with increasing availability due to the sequential blocking model. Today, we will discuss the second saga they called the fantasy fiction saga. In this saga, we switch from a blocking communication model to a non-blocking one while maintaining the atomicity constraint.

item.title: Sagas Quantatively: Epic Saga
item.description: When we transition to microservices, each service owns its data. Achieving transactions across multiple services isn’t as straightforward as with a single monolithic database. One way to address this challenge is through sagas, which simulate distributed transactions using a series of local transactions. This approach was popularized by Chris Richardson and later analyzed by Mark Richards and Neal Ford in their book ‘Sotware Architecture: The Hard Parts’.
